Name: Quizalofop
Description: 2-{4-[(6-chloroquinoxalin-2-yl)oxy]phenoxy}propanoic acid is a monocarboxylic acid that is 2-phenoxypropanoic acid in which the phenyl group is substituted at the para position by a (6-chloroquinoxalin-2-yl)oxy group. It is a quinoxaline derivative, an aromatic ether, a monocarboxylic acid and an organochlorine compound.

plant_translocations.content: An experiment was conducted to evaluate the translocation pattern of 14C-glyphosate and 14C-quizalofop in five quackgrass biotypes at two stages of growth. Whole plant translocation differed between stages for each herbicide. The percentage of 14C-glyphosate and 14C-quizalofop in the leafwash and in the treated leaf did not differ among biotypes, but differences occurred for the translocation to the underground parts. The partitioning of the 14C-glyphosate and 14C-quizalofop in the treated crown, other crowns, propagating rhizomes, and other rhizomes differed among biotypes. On a disintegration per minute (DPM) mg-1 basis, differences among biotypes were found with 14C-glyphosate but much less with 14C-quizalofop. Metabolism of 14C-quizalofop in the treated leaf was similar in the two biotypes tested except for the percentage of polar metabolites 1 d after treatment. The percentage of 14C-quizalofop available for translocation was the same in both biotypes.
plant_translocations.reference: Tardif, F. J., & Leroux, G. D. (1991). Translocation of glyphosate and quizalofop and metabolism of quizalofop in quackgrass biotypes (Elytrigia repens). Weed Technology, 5(3), 525-531.

method.Apply Location: Foliar application (one 8-μl droplet was placed on the adaxial surface of the second fully expanded leaf on the main stem)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Plants were grown in plastic pots (15 cm diameter) containing a standard potting mix in growth chambers with 16-h day at 20°C and 8-h night at 15°C. Plants were irrigated daily and fertilized weekly.
method.Chemical Preparation: Quizalofop was prepared by adding phenyl [U]-14C-quizalofop ethyl ester to a commercial quizalofop ethyl ester solution for 0.75 MBq per 8-μl droplet.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Commercial formulations of glyphosate (450 and 900 g ae/ha) and quizalofop ethyl ester (100 and 150 g ai/ha with 1% v/v petroleum oil) were sprayed in 225 L/ha.
method.Other Information: Five quackgrass biotypes (2, 7, 8, 9, and 10) were tested at two growth stages (3-4 leaf and 6-7 leaf).

plant_translocations.content: The translocation pattern and distribution in rhizomes of 14C-glyphosate, 14C-quizalofop, and 14C-sucrose was examined in five quackgrass biotypes. Translocation of radioactivity in the different plant parts varied among biotypes. Translocation in the whole plant after treatment with the three 14C-chemicals varied among biotypes but was not correlated with their tolerance to herbicides. Detailed analysis of distribution of radioactivity in the primary rhizome showed that more 14C was found in the apical sections after treatment with 14C-sucrose. A similar pattern was observed after 14C-glyphosate application with all biotypes except one. Very low radioactivity was found in rhizomes after 14C-quizalofop application, but a preferential accumulation in apical sections of the primary rhizome was detected in two biotypes. The tolerance of one biotype to glyphosate was explained by the absence of radioactivity accumulation in the apical sections of the rhizome.
plant_translocations.reference: Tardif, F. J., & Leroux, G. D. (1993). Translocation of glyphosate, quizalofop, and sucrose in quackgrass (Elytrigia repens) biotypes. Weed Science, 41(3), 341-346.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Five quackgrass biotypes were propagated using single-node rhizome segments and planted in plastic pots (125-mm diameter) filled with standard potting mix. The plants were grown in growth chambers with 16-hour day at 20°C and 8-hour night at 15°C, maximum photon flux density of 300 μE/m2/s, daily irrigation, and weekly fertilization with a solution containing 0.2 g/L each of N, P, and K.
method.Chemical Preparation: Phenyl [U]-14C-quizalofop ethyl ester (specific activity 0.75 MBq per 8-μl droplet) was mixed with a commercial quizalofop ethyl ester solution. 14C[U]-sucrose (specific activity 0.75 MBq per 8-μl droplet) was prepared in distilled water containing 1% non-ionic adjuvant.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Plants were first sprayed with unlabeled glyphosate (900 g ae/ha) or quizalofop ethyl ester (240 g ai/ha) along with 1% petroleum oil using an experimental sprayer. After drying, 8 μl of the respective 14C-labeled herbicide or 14C-sucrose was applied to the treated leaf.
method.Other Information: The study used five quackgrass biotypes,

plant_translocations.content: Laboratory experiments with 14C-herbicides were conducted with grain sorghum as an indicator species to determine the effects of imposed moisture stress on absorption, precent recovery, and acropetal and basipetal translocation of the butyl ester of fluazifop, the methyl ester of haloxyfop, the ethyl ester of quizalofop, and sethoxydim. Haloxyfop was the only herbicide where recovery decreased between the 3-and 48-h interval. All plants absorbed more of the herbicide at the 48-h interval than at the 3- or 6-h interval under both stressed and non-stressed conditions. Increased drought stress caused more acropetal movement with fluazifop and sethoxydim and less acropetal movement with quizalofop at the 3-h interval. Basipetal transloation, although different among herbicides, responded similarly to imposed moisture stress, which decreased basipetal translocation approximately 19%.
plant_translocations.reference: Reynolds, D. B., Wheless, T. G., Basler, E., & Murray, D. S. (1988). Moisture stress effects on absorption and translocation of four foliar-applied herbicides. Weed Technology, 2(4), 437-441.

method.Plant Grown Condition: The plants were grown in a controlled environment chamber with a temperature regime of 29°C days and 21°C nights, a daytime relative humidity of 80% (±5%), and a 12-h photoperiod at an average photosynthetic photon flux density of 240 μE·m−2·s−1.
method.Chemical Preparation: Herbicides fluazifop (0.05 μCi/μl, carboxyl-14C), quizalofop (0.05 μCi/μl, phenol-14C), haloxyfop (0.05 μCi/μl, phenoxy-UL-14C), and sethoxydim (0.05 μCi/μl, H4-14C) were dissolved in acetone with 0.47% (v/v) octoxynol added.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Two drops of the respective 14C-herbicide solution were applied to the second most fully expanded true leaf 3 cm above the leaf collar.
method.Other Information: The experimental design was a randomized complete block with a 3x2x4 factorial treatment arrangement and four replications
